summary: This is a legal filing by Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys opposing the government's request to delay disclosure of materials related to alleged victims of Jeffrey Epstein who do not implicate Maxwell. The defense argues these materials are exculpatory Brady material and material to preparing the defense, and that the government has not shown good cause for delay.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, accused of facilitating Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse. Her defense attorneys are opposing the government's request to delay disclosure of certain materials.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier accused of sexual abuse of minors. The document discusses materials related to his alleged victims.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, to whom the defense letter is addressed.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP who signed the letter on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney copied on the letter, presumably part of the defense team.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney copied on the letter, presumably part of the defense team.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Attorney copied on the letter, presumably part of the defense team.

persons.name: Bobbi C. Stemheim
persons.context: Attorney copied on the letter, presumably part of the defense team.

persons.name: Accuser-1
persons.context: An alleged victim of Jeffrey Epstein who filed a defamation lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell in 2015, which led to the perjury charges.

connections.description: The government's theory, as described in the document, is that Maxwell was Epstein's 'madam' and principal facilitator of his sexual abuse scheme.
Accuser-1 sued Maxwell for defamation after Maxwell denied her allegations, leading to the depositions that resulted in perjury charges.
Everdell is writing the legal filing on behalf of his client, Ghislaine Maxwell.
Cohen is copied on the defense letter, indicating he is part of Maxwell's legal team.

events.title: Epstein's Non-Prosecution Agreement Executed
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein entered into a non-prosecution agreement with the government.

events.title: Accuser-1 Files Motion to Join NPA Challenge
events.description: Accuser-1 filed a motion to join a lawsuit challenging the validity of Epstein's 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Defamation Lawsuit Filed Against Maxwell
events.description: Accuser-1 sued Ghislaine Maxwell for defamation after Maxwell publicly denied her allegations.

events.title: Maxwell's Depositions in Defamation Case
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was deposed twice in the defamation case, leading to the perjury charges (Counts Five and Six) in the indictment.

events.title: Government Requests Delay in Disclosure
events.description: The government filed a letter requesting permission to delay disclosure of photographs and documents relating to certain alleged victims.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The defense argues that materials related to alleged victims of Jeffrey Epstein who do not accuse Ghislaine Maxwell of participation are exculpatory Brady evidence that must be disclosed.
The defense claims the government interviewed 'dozens' of alleged victims of Epstein's sexual abuse, many of whom do not implicate Maxwell.
The perjury charges against Maxwell stem from her 2015 depositions in a defamation lawsuit filed by an alleged victim ('Accuser-1').
The defense contends that evidence of Epstein's sexual activities after 1997 is relevant to the perjury charges because Maxwell was asked about her general knowledge of Epstein's sexual activities.

The government's stated reason for delaying disclosure—that it might deter other alleged victims from coming forward—is argued by the defense to be insufficient to establish 'good cause' under Rule 16(d)(1).
